title: Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art
text: Although the collection is not really large they have a few very good paintings, mostly 19th and 20th century. Terrific early Klimt canvas, Munch, Magritte, Chagall, Dali, Ernst, a couple of good Van Goghs,. Also they have one painting by Pavel Tchelitchev on display, albeit only one even though they have a few more in the vault. Old masters are represented by Hals, van Dyck, Goya. The American section has a couple of Andrew Wyeth paintings, Sargent. The only problem they keep the surrealists in glassed frames and the light reflects so badly in the room that the colors and the paintings are difficult to see (thus 3 stars).

title: Dingmans Falls
text: The road to the visitor center is closed. You have to park near Rt 209 and walk a mile to the center. The road is paved and it's an easy walk. From there the boardwalk to both Silver Thread and Dingmans Falls is well maintained. Climbing the stair to the top of DF is fine too although the view from the top is not as dramatic.

title: Dockside Brewery
text: Large selection of beer but the beer quality is just OK. We ordered 4 different beers and all were mediocre, nothing to write home about. The food was even worse, nearly tasteless. The staff were nice and helpful.

title: Sanibel Island Northern Beach
text: I'm not sure if the parking regulations are the same throughout the island as we've been to this beach but Sanibel Island Northern Beach but if they are you'd better off flying to the French Riviera. It's $5 an hour and strictly enforced. So if you plan on spending a full day at the beach you will tap a bill for $40-$50 for parking fees alone. Besides the beach itself can be described as mediocre at best. We stayed in Sarasota and decided to explore Sanibel. It turned out to be a complete waste of time and money. Sarasota and St Pete beaches are so much better it's not worth the trouble of driving to Sanibel.

title: Taft Museum of Art
text: Absolutely wonderful! A small private collection of the Tafts located in their formed mansion showing their personal taste. A Rembrandt and three Halses are definite highlights but the collection ranges from Corneille de Lyon to Dutch painters (de Hoogh, ter Borch, Steen) to Goya, Turner, Corot and Sorolla. A couple of good Sargents, the portrait of Robert Louis Stevenson being one of them, and an interesting painting by Henry F. Farny. Excellent!

title: Columbus Museum of Art
text: Did I confuse this highly admired institution with another one? After so much praise on tis site? In fact it's a very, very, very weak museum. The weakest of the 4 major Ohio museums. I would put the Cleveland at the top of the list, with Toledo's and Cincinnati's sharing the second and third place. And strangely enough this museum charges a hefty fee plus $5 for parking. There was interesting room with good French impressionists though.

title: Cincinnati Art Museum
text: Overall it's a good museum. The collection is not large but presents a few good paintings, Hals, ter Borch, El Greco, Botticelli, Titian, Bronzino among others. Good canvases by Courbet, Kokoschka, Rivera, Chagall, Soutine, French impressionists.

title: Saint Louis Art Museum
text:
It's an excellent regional museum. We visited it back in 2007 while it was in renovation and only parts of their collection could be seen. Now everything is finished and the collection is on display in full.
The old masters include Titian, El Greco, Vasary (not my favorite but rather a rarity), Hals, ter Borch and a bunch of other Dutch painters. Good collection of 19th and 20th century art featuring Courbet, Modigliani, Lipchitz, Chagall, Magritte, Ernst, Sorolla, German expressionists (entire room of Max Beckmann), impressionists with two portraits by Anders Zorn. Terrific collection of pre-columbian art, Maya, Teotihuacan, Zapotec, Aztec, Inka, Nasca, and an amazing stand of Mississippian copper.

title: Fairfield Inn & Suites Cincinnati North/Sharonville
text: Except for the lobby the hotel is super dated. Old elevator, old carpets, old bathrooms with cracked sinks, old A/C. We had a double room which was fairly clean and seemed to have a more or less fresh coat of paint but the blue and orange combination of colors wasn't very inspiring. Breakfast was strangely dispensed. There were three couples in front of us trying to register for breakfast or something of the sort, and the process looked so tedious that we left with coffee only. But the strangest thing happened around 6 pm when someone knocked at our door, and while I was approaching it to open he opened our door with his key. The latch stopped it, the man apologized (happened to be a polite guy!), and when I looked into the peephole I saw him opening the door of the room across the hall and walking into that room where someone else was present. Interesting, isn't it? I hope the management has a good explanation here.
place: Fairfield Inn & Suites Cincinnati North / Sharonville

title: Courtyard St. Louis Brentwood
text: Good solid Courtyard. As expected. The room was well appointed, clean, quiet. Good bedding. The location was convenient, close to the university and museum and not far from the highway. Nice courteous staff. There was a Starbucks across the parking lot but the line of cars was always huge there and we just passed it by.

title: Courtyard by Marriott Springfield Airport
text: We didn't have any particular business to attend in Springfield and just had a stopover to make a long drive from Dallas to St Louis a bit easier. This hotel served the purpose perfectly. It's well-maintained, with a nice lobby, good clean room, nice bathroom facilities, welcoming staff, close to the highway. Overall it was a comfortable place.

title: Oklahoma State Capitol
text: It's a grand building with a beautiful Indian chief statue above the cupola. We didn't go inside as we were pressed for time driving from Dallas to Missouri but had I known of its grandeur we would have definitely took a tour of it. There is a special visitors parking but you can drive around and stop temporarily at free assigned spots for better view.

title: Texas State Capitol
text: It's an interestig building. Its pinkish-brownish facade is pretty impressive. We did not go inside as we jjust stopped by on our way from San Antonio to Dallas and didn't have time for a tour of the capitol. The surrounding area is quite nice too.

title: Center of the Universe
text: It's the most stupid attraction I've ever seen. There's nothing to do and nothing to see there. And it's hard to find as there's no visible sign in sight and your GPS simply points at the sidewalk. Downtown Tulsa is very nice though so we drove around to compensate for this waste of time and effort.

title: San Antonio Museum of Art
text: San Antonio Museum of Art has a very small collection of paintings but the antiquities collection was a pleasant surprise. Especially the Ancient Egyptian art. Also Ancient Greece is well represented and the Roman portraiture exhibit contains a few excellent pieces. The parking is conveniently located across the street.

title: San Antonio Missions National Historical Park
text: The park consists of three missions which were part of the effort of Spanish colonization of the region. Interestingly the Alamo fortress originally was the first mission in the area. We saw the mission of San Jose only as we are not that much into Spanish colonial history and architecture. It's free admission and the ranger at the entrance provides some information and distributes the park's maps. Parking is plentiful. The place is easy to find.
place: San Antonio Missions National Historical Park

title: The Alamo
text: If you use GPS type in The Alamo, otherwise you will be directed to Alamo, TX on the US-Mexican border. The place was packed on a Sunday, all guided tours were sold out. You can walk in to this piece of American history and wander around on your own though. I was surprised to find out that originally it was built as a mission.

title: Courtyard San Antonio Downtown/Market Square
text: Good standard Courtyard. Close to the downtown, 5-10 minute drive. We had a room on the first floor with a sliding door although facing the parking. The room was good, clean, quiet, everything in working order, The bed was comfortable, front desk staff courteous.

title: Dallas Museum of Art
text: For a major US metropolis like Dallas to have such mediocre museum is both unusual and unexpected. Their pre-columbian section has a couple good pieces though.

title: The Menil Collection
text: Very good collection, well structured and organized. Rene Magritte and Max Ernst are nicely presented. Photography is not allowed. The museum's store is located across the street offering very good selection of art books.

title: Museum of Fine Arts, Houston
text: It's an excellent regional museum. Its two buildings contain a well-structured collection of paintings and ancient artifacts. Old masters are represented by Pintoricchio, Botticelli, Aert de Gelder, Rembrandt, Memling. Nice collection of impressionists, plus Sorolla, Chagall, Soutine, Modigliani, Munch, Magritte, Dali, Matisse, Picasso, Rivera.

title: The Ringling
text: The Ringling is a very good museum. We've seen their art collection only. They have a few nice canvases. Also they have a small exhibition of two portraits by Hals of Pieter Jacobsz Olycan, one from their own collection, and the other one from the Hals Museum in Haarlem, Holland.

title: Courtyard Houston-West University
text: It's a very good hotel. It's located near the highway but the street is very quiet. The room was nice and clean. They charge $10 for parking. The hotel's proximity to downtown Houston and its museums is a big plus.

title: Saint Pete Beach
text: It's a pretty good beach. It's not as good as the beaches in Sarasota but it's not bad at all. There was plenty of parking.

title: Selva Grill
text: The appetizers are good but ceviche is subpar. Not only it's not even close to being authentic Peruvian it's not good at all. On top of that the waiter confused our order with someone else's.

title: Lauren Rogers Museum of Art
text: It's a very small museum in a small town. Free admission. Very nice and helpful staff. Plenty of street parking. Located in a very nice and old area of the town. We came to see a painting by Frits Thaulow in their collection, not his best work but still worth the detour.

title: Courtyard Beaumont
text: It's strange to see so many negative reviews here as I found this hotel to be quite decent. It's not a 5-star hotel but a typical solid Courtyard it is. It looked noisy and hectic as there were a lot of people in the lobby but the hotel did a good job with regard to sound insulation as they installed glass doors in the corridors leading to the rooms on the ground floor. The room was clean and quiet and looked recently renovated with decent bathroom facilities. The staff were nice and polite.

title: Fairfield Inn Pensacola I-10
text: I think some reviewers here confuse this hotel with Fairfield Inn & Suites Pensacola West I-10 which is probably better. This one is Fairfield Inn Pensacola I-10. It's an old and dated hotel with dated furniture, dated bathroom, and even blankets and pillows and sheets look dated. The room was so dated it was impossible to determine whether it was clean. Very poor sound insulation as the noise from the highway traffic could be heard all night. Free breakfast was a mendacious claim as there was practically no breakfast, only yogurt and coffee. To be fair we came down for breakfast pretty late, shortly after 8, but I have a strong suspicion that even at 6 am the feast of King Solomon it was not. The staff seemed to be oblivious to what was happening and were busy chatting to each other. I gave it 2 stars only because of its proximity to I-10 which makes it a convenient stop.

title: North Carolina Museum of Art
text: It's a good regional museum with a nice collection of antiquities (especially ancient Egypt) and paintings but it's the most haphazardly structured exhibit I've seen. For some strange reason the curators mixed works of artists from different periods. The European art collection is impressive featuring Giotto, Raphael, Hals, Lievens, French Impressionists, etc.

title: Monument Avenue
text: Monument Avenue should be renamed Postament Avenue. Or install statues of Mickey & Minnie Mouse or something on those pedestals to make use of them.

title: Fairfield Inn & Suites Brunswick
text: It's a decent hotel for an overnight stay. It looks either recently renovated or pretty new. The room was clean and quiet. Very friendly and heplful staff. Breakfast was regular covid style. Convenient location.

title: Fairfield Inn & Suites by Marriott Raleigh Cary
text: Very good value for you buck. The hotel looks fairly new. Very COVID-considerate as they even provide gloves to pour coffee from the coffee pot. The room was clean and quiet. Relatively good selection of breakfast foodstuffs, they tried to supply even hot items as far as the restrictions permitted.
place: Fairfield Inn & Suites by Marriott Raleigh Cary

title: Virginia Museum of Fine Arts
text: Even though the building looks very impressive the collection is pretty small. The highlights include the Imperial Russian family Faberge jewelry exhibit (the largest of the sort I've ever seen gathered in one place), and paintings by Ter Borch, Goya, and Dali.

title: Museum of Fine Arts
text: We had a couple of hours to spare in St Pete and decided to go to the Museum of Fine Arts. We hold a reciprocal membership for the last 15 years allowing us admission to over 200 museums throughout North America. But here we were informed that the museum ceased to participate in the program. Which is ok, circumstances change, but the problem is that the museum is still listed as participating. So the management gets the on star, they should have provided the services to the members while the listing is being updated. As for the museum itself we saw it in 2003 and I wasn't overly impressed with its collection. As far as I remeber it is a 3-star museum.

title: Worcester Art Museum
text: Terrific regional museum. Relatively small but with a lot to see. NIce antiquities collection, very good collection of European paintings including such rarities as Jan Lievens and Judith Leyster (they even claim to have a da Vinci). I've known of this museum for years but couldn't find time to stop by. Should take 2-3 hours to visit. They have a couple of parking lots but they are small and were completely full . Timed tickets sold online.

title: Springhill Suites Boston Andover
text: Good hotel. Clean and quiet room. The heater/aircond was a bit noisy , especially bothersome at night. Nice staff. You have to pre-order breakfast and the selection is covid style, limited and not very nutritious, but we did not expect too great of a feast due to the pandemic anyway. Other than that it was pretty adequate.

title: Minute Man National Historical Park
text: The cradle of the American Revolution, this park must be great in the summer, since even covered with snow it really is beautiful. Walking the icy paths was challenging while we tried to navigate it but on the positive side there was not a lot of visitors. Don't miss the grave stone of the fallen British soldiers next to the obelisk.

title: Lyons Falls Waterfall
text: To see the Lyons Falls Waterfall you have to cross the bridge over Black River (from west to east) and take the next left onto Rt 39 N. There is a small parking area about a thousand feet from the turn from where you can walk practically next to the falls. A better viewing point of the falls is located anothe half a mile up north. The presence of the power station spoils the experience somewhat.

title: Ausable Chasm
text: The waterfalls are impressive but you can observe it only from the bridge as all park facilities are closed. The visitors center is open only to sell souvenirs, no other services, not even restrooms. The park can be accessed but there was plenty of ice so we decided against taking a walk there. Parking lots on both sides of the road on both sides of the bridge.

title: Courtyard Albany Clifton Park
text: Good hotel for a short stay as expected from Courtyard. The room was clean, quiet. The matrass was a bit soft. As an added bonus they provide free breakfast unlike usual Courtyard. Close to the highway, easy to find.
place: COURTYARD BY MARRIOTT ALBANY CLIFTON PARK

title: Chittenango Falls
text: Beautiful waterfalls. You can see it from the road some 500 feet from the park entrance. There's a path from the parking lot with a steep descent which leads to a small bridge at the bottom of the ravine where you can get to the other side of the stream with a steep climb up. I guess the view from the bridge is terrific but the steps were so slippery that we decided not to take the risk. You can get to the other side using the road bridge over the top of the waterfalls.

title: Residence Inn Syracuse Downtown at Armory Square
text: The building is home to both Residence Inn and Courtyard. Good room, clean and quiet. Very close to I-690. The location is pretty much at the city center, with Niagara Mohawk building and Clinton Square around the corner. They charge $10 for covered parking but I think you can park in front of the hotel for free.
place: Residence Inn Syracuse Downtown at Armory Square

title: Ludlowville Falls
text:
GPS directions are bad. It made us go to Salmon Creek Rd which is located behind the falls with no access to it. When you arrive at the intersection of Ludlowville Rd and Mill Rd just cross Mill Rd to the small parking lot of Ludlowville Park on your right. From there walk by the children's playground to the fence along Salmon Creek and find a good viewing spot to see the falls. Unfortunately there's no access to the falls other than encroaching on a private property. Besides the ground was pretty soft so we did not venture to find a path down.
The waterfalls are small but beautiful although not as grand as the nearby Taughannock Falls.

title: Taughannock Falls
text:
There are two entrances to the park, from Rt 89 which is very scenic and runs along Lake Cayuga , and from Rt 96. The former has a small parking lot next to the trail leading to the falls and a large parking across the road. From here you can take a fairly easy walk to the foot of the falls along the picturesque river valley which takes about 30 minutes each way. Then drive thru the park towards Rt 96 to visit the overlook for a stunning view of the falls.
It was the first stop of our NYS waterfall tour this winter and it turned out to be one of the most beautiful ones.

title: Fairfield Inn by Marriott Ann Arbor
text: Inexpensive hotel. Good for a night stay. The room was really small though with such a tiny bathroom that the sink was situated in the room two feet from the bed. And the A/C was somewhat noisy. Breakfast was covid style . The staff are nice and helpful.
place: Fairfield Inn by Marriott Ann Arbor

title: Hill-Stead Museum
text:
Describing it as "a large collection of French Impressionist paintings" is an exaggeration. It's more of a country house with a small private art collection but what makes it exceptional is the way those impressionist paintings are presented. I can't say if the curators and technicians used a scientific approach here but the method of lighting they employ produces a phenomenal effect. The paintings in question, definitely the highlights of the entire collection, namely: Monet's haystacks (2) and landscape; Degas pastel and pink ballerinas; and a portrait by Manet make a viewer redefine the idea of a masterpiece. Real feast of color. Bravo!
The admission is pretty steep for the art collection alone (although they make an emphasis on the mansion and the grounds) but I saw it in a different light, literally. )) A guided tour is every hour on the hour and is mandatory. No pictures allowed.

title: Fairfield Inn & Suites Boston Cambridge
text: The hotel is pretty good, modern building, clean room (although not very spacious), nice friendly staff, but the area it's located in is somewhat strange. It's not a place where you would dream of taking a walk. Breakfast was covid-style, so I can't comment on it. They have a good parking site (paid). It's not overly expensive and convenient if you have a car and only need a place to sleep.

title: St. Volodymyr Ukrainian Catholic Church
text: This is a log-cabin style building, nothing close to Eastern European architecture. The orthodox-shaped domes imitate it to some degree but it's just an imitation. It was closed at the time of our visit, so no idea about the interior. It's worth a detour if you're driving in the area along the Delaware River but a special trip wouldn't be warranted.

title: Doc Ponds
text: We asked a local policeman about good restaurants in Stowe and this one was second on his list, The Bench being his first choice. But the latter happened to be a few hundred yards further down the road so we stopped at Doc Ponds. The half chicken Vermont style was really good. They have a decent selection of beer. The service was good too. And Stowe is quite a nice town though it seems to be a bit pricey around the time of foliage watching season.

title: Waterfront Park
text: The park itself is rather small but they built a nice boardwalk along the lake shore and the views of the sunset from it are breathtaking. Parking in the area is pretty tight but manageable.

title: Church Street Marketplace
text: Nice spot overall but a very strange neighborhood approaching it from the south. Lots of stores and restaurants evidently popular with university students.

title: Residence Inn Burlington Colchester
text: Good hotel, it looks pretty new. It's nicely located right outside Burlington in quiet secluded settings. Huge parking. Very helpful and friendly front desk staff giving great recommendations for sightseeing and restaurants. We got a bedroom suite with a gas fireplace. The room turned out to be not as spacious as the picture on the hotel's site suggested but it was good enough and quite cozy to spend a couple of nights there. Breakfast was covid-style so it's hard to judge how good or bad it would be under normal circumstances.

title: This church is in Marcapata, not in Cusco!
text: This small rural church is in Marcapata, not in Cusco. In fact it's 3-4 hours and 200 km away from Cusco. I was the one to request this entry in TA, and the TA editors, being the dummies that they are, screwed it up from the very start showing the church's location in Cusco at Plaza de Arnas. I wrote them numerous times pointing to the error but to no avail. Now there are only 2 more reviews addressing the subject properly. One is by Ricardo M (Aug 2015) with an excellent picture of the locals renovating the thatched roof of the church, and another one by Silvia V wrote (Sep 2016) with good photos of it. All other reviewers wrote wrong reviews through no fault of their own.
place: Templo de San Francisco de Asis de Marcapata

title: Historic Huguenot Street
text: The historic part of Huguenot Street is fairly small, it takes less than an hour to walk it at a very leisurely pace but the town of New Paltz is a cute place

title: Fairfield Inn & Suites by Marriott Rehoboth Beach
text: Nice hotel, pretty standard layout for a Fairfield. Conveniently located on Rt 1. Breakfast was COVID-style - no hot items, you have to indicate what you want, but considering the circumstances the selection was a bit better than at other comparable places.
place: Fairfield Inn & Suites by Marriott Rehoboth Beach

title: Farnsworth Art Museum
text: It's a small museum with its collection of mostly American artists . We wanted to see an Andrew Wyeth exhibition, small too, but nice. If not for that the admission would be pretty high. Parking is right across the street.

title: Fort Knox
text: It's been a surprising discovery as we decided to take coastal roads from Bangor to Brunswick. An interesting place with interesting story. Never expected to see a military installation from the mid-1800 in this part of the country.

title: Fairfield Inn & Suites Brunswick
text: It' gets a bit tricky driving Rt 1 south as you have to make a U-turn, then take immediately to the right and exit to stay on Rt 1. The hotel is a standard Fairfield, good value for money. Due to covid they have a grab-and-go breakfast which is quite mediocre, but it's understandable considering the circumstances. It's pretty close to the center and the university.

title: Courtyard Bangor
text: It's a good mid-range hotel. I would rate it 5-star if not for the packed-to-go breakfast which is a covid dictated necessity . You can buy starbucks coffee at the bar in the morning though. The room was as expected with a quiet yet powerful A/C. The staff are nice and helpful although they do not provide any room services including cleaning to minimize staff interaction with guests, another covid fallout.

title: Shannon's Unshelled
text: The listed address, 11 Granary Way that is, is no longer. If you drive using GPS start looking for parking as soon as you get to the Granary way intersection and proceed on foot. You have to pass number 11 as the place is located in a small wagon on wheels. It's a movable feast now. We drove from Bath to try their lobster roll which happened to be good. It comes with 2 small sides of fries and coleslaw. We ordered onion rings in addition and they were bland.

title: Best Western Sault Ste. Marie
text: It's a good hotel with nice and helpful personnel. Due to the covid pandemic breakfast was prepacked and distributed by the front desk. The selection of items is a weak point. Other than that it's a good place for one-two nights.

title: Champlain Mountain
text: This is our favorite trail. It's not crowded and not too strenuous though there are a few difficult spots there. The views at the top and along the way are terrific. There's a small parking area on the left side of the road some 300 feet past the Beaver Pond. Park and walk about 50 feet back to the trail. Parking may be a problem, it's a small overlook, just 6-7 cars, but there's another overlook area a quarter mile down the road.

title: Atlantic Brewing Company
text: We didn't try their food, just bought beer from them. Unfortunately they were out of Blueberry and IPA but two of my favorites, Thunder Hole Ale and Bar Harbor Real Ale, were in store.

title: Smokey's BBQ & Lobster
text: We tried three lobster pounds this time: Lunts (by mistake and it was soooo bad), Trenton Bridge (our favorite from our previous visits to Acadia) and Smokey's . And the latter is the best. The grilled lobster is excellent, the smoked is good too, and their sides are pure magic, particularly baked beans and onion strings. Very friendly and professional staff. We brought beer from Atlantic Brewing Co and they were fine with that. The place is quite popular, outside seating may be tight.

title: Trenton Bridge Lobster Pound
text: It's a good solid place. Lobster is well prepared. Service is good. You are allowed to bring your own beer. Bear in mind they are closed on Sundays.

title: Gateway Lunts Lobster Pound
text: We stopped there by mistake as we confused it with Trenton Bridge Lobster Pound (having been there some 10 years ago we simply didn't remember the name of the plalce). It's just bad. We ordered a take-out and specifically asked twice to crack the lobster shell. Of course that was ignored. Our lobsters were wrapped in an old newspaper but we found it out only when we opened the package at our picnic site, absolutely disgusting. No napkins or crackers were provided. The lobster was not bad but that's expected from a lobster pound. Avoid. Go to either Trenton Bridge or better yet to Smoky.

title: Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park
text: Nice park,lots of trails. You have to buy a pass at the visitors center. Have ample supply of water and bring sandwiches if you plan on staying there long as there' are no stores or restaurants in the park.

title: Keweenaw National Historical Park
text: Keweenaw National Historical Park is just remnants of a prosperous mining town gone bust. The entire site occupies two or three blocks with a few grand-looking buildings of the turn-of-the-century style. If you venture a couple of blocks away you'll see the site of the Italian Hall where the famous tragic event gave birth to the phrase "shouting fire in a crowded theater." It took us less than an hour.

title: Peterson's Fish Market
text: We bought smoked fish at the store only so I have no opinion of the restaurant. We bought smoked whitefish, smoked trout and smoked herring. All were good.

title: Keweenaw Brewing Company
text: Good local brewery though it was pretty crowded. Their Red Jacket Amber Ale is very good. They sell it in cans which makes it suspect but we had it in a restaurant before and knew it was good.

title: Joey's Seafood & Grill
text: Surprisingly it's a very good seafood place. Fish was prepared just right. Excellent service. They are very strict with regard to the covid situation.

title: Magnuson Hotel Copper Crown
text: The hotel has an unusual motel/hotel layout with two-door rooms providing entry both to the hall and to the courtyard where the parking is. Pretty convenient if you're concerned with minimizing your exposure to coronavirus. The room has somewhat dated furniture but is clean and quiet. As a nice and thoughtful touch with regard to the virus, they deliver your breakfast to your room though the quality of packaged foodstuffs leaves much more to be desired.

title: Holiday Inn Express Houghton - Keweenaw
text: Good hotel, looks new, everything working. The room was quite spacious, clean and quiet. The only problem was breakfast: limited selection and poor quality of food. We stayed there for one night........

title: Sturgeon point lighthouse
text: The lighthouse is closed because of the virus but the grounds are open. I was a bit surprised to see some people using the sand dunes as a beach.

title: Eagle Harbor Lighthouse and Museums
text: Surprisingly there were 3-4 dozen people when we visited. Both the lighthouse and the museums are closed due to the pandemic I guess. The grounds are open so you can walk around and see the views. The parking is small and it was pretty full (July 4 weekend).

title: Eagle Harbor Lighthouse
text: The lighthouse and the museums are closed due to the pandemic I guess. The grounds are open so you can walk around and see the views. The parking is small and it was pretty full (July 4 weekend).

title: Point Iroquois Light
text: Both the lighthouse and the museum are closed but you can walk the grounds. I was surprised to see a half dozen cars at the parking lot when we came in after 6 pm. Looks like a popular place.

title: Chapel Rock
text:
If you drive there bear in mind that the 5-mile road leading to the site from H-58 is a dirt road with plenty of potholes. So plan on negotiating it thru a cloud of dust with an average speed of about 10 mph. The GPS directions are incorrect (we used our car GPS and Google - both with the same problem). The right fork where it directs you to go is closed. We decided to try it on foot only to turn back after a hundred yards as we realized it wasn't a good idea. So take a left fork if there are no cars parked along both sides of the road. Otherwise find a good spot to park and proceed to the parking lot on foot : it's good for about 4 dozen cars, you're lucky to find a spot if someone just left or if you managed to come in among the first few dozen visitors. So on July 4th if you're not there around 6 am perish the thought, just find a good spot and walk. It's less than half a mile from the fork to the parking lot.
At the parking lot you'll find a map stand with all points of interest and trails. It's a little over 3 miles to the Chapel Rock and the trail is pretty easy.

title: Lomen Stave Church
text:
Getting to the church is a bit tricky even though one can see the church from the road. There's a no-entry sign at the entrance to the dirt road leading to the church and a small plate says specifically "For Lomen Stavkyrkje". So you have to use the small parking lot at the intersection of E16 and Ellestadvegen and proceed to the church on foot. There was no visible path off this dirt road leading directly to the church as the field in front of it is all grass about 2-foot tall, but this dirt road takes you to a barn with a "Private" sign posted on it. The path to the church is right behind the barn.

The church was closed at the time of our visit but you can open the gates to walk the grounds. There are magnificent carved portals and a stand-alone bell tower.

There is another entry for this attraction on TA titled "Lomen stavkyrkje." This is a third or fourth time I have to post this review as TA editors, being the lazy jackasses that they are, prefer to delete my review instead of merging identical entries. Also, on a number of occasions they had deleted my reviews for not adhering to their standards even though some of those reviews were marked as helpful by other TA members. But of course, TA editors in their infinite wisdom know better what's helpful. TripAdvisor used to be a great site but it turned into junk.

title: Grunauer
text: Very nice place. Great selection of beers. The waiter knew his stuff and gave excellent recommendations for both drink and food. The ambience is nice but can be a bit noisy
